d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Subtitled "Martin Luther, the Reformation, and the Conflicts that Continue to Shape Our World." Brad Gregory was Anna's professor for her Freshman Humanities Seminar at Notre Dame and his academic specialty is the era of the Reformation. This book is not as good as his lecture on the Reformation that he did for the Learning Company (which I listened to over the summer) in dealing with the events of the era. It is more in depth in evaluating the ongoing effects of the Reformation on modern culture, particularly in the United States. A good introduction for anyone who wants to understand what happened without endless discussions on the finer points of theology.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An Amazon e-book; I ordered the book after reading a review in the Wall Street Journal. Overall, shallow and disappointing - more like a movie script. The review did not discuss how much this was a send-up of the Oxford Analytica scandal in the aftermath of the 2016 US presidential election. But Mr. Mount offers no evidence that he understands how "data mining" works, and offers only shallow mockery of those who use these techniques in advancing their interests. Mr. Mount does write with pleasing style and a certain understated sense of humor. He is able to provide compelling caricatures of people of low moral standards and questionable intentions. But he offers no insight into why they act as they do, and his "sympathetic" characters are equally caricatures. If he were a painter, he would be a street artist who provides quick profile sketches. Perhaps his best moment was his rendering of a Donald Trump take-down of a candidate for whom his narrator was working. Without ever mentioning Trump's name, it was clear from the speech who he was portraying. Yet if Trump is one of the "bad guys", what are we to make of the fact that he quickly sees through the "anti-hero" of the story and summarily fires him while the narrator stands idly by while his boss dates (and then impregnates) his daughter, attempts to seduce his wife and steals the one interesting job that he had assigned to him? All fluff and no substance.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Second Hand Time: The Last of the Soviets

d:simplesect.d:para: An recorded book that I checked out from the library; the checkout ended with about two hours left in the book. This is a collection of interviews of residents of the former Soviet Union conducted by Ms. Alexievich. Although it is clear that her sympathies are with those who wish to bring liberal democracy and human rights to Russia, she allows people from all spectrums to speak freely of their feelings of the death of the Soviet Union and the attempt by the Russian Federation to implement democracy and a free market economy. It is very depressing, yet very enlightening on human nature in response to very challenging conditions. On one hand, it is difficult to listen to those who still cling to Soviet ideology and who speak with all the depth and subtlety of writers for Pravda or Isvestia. Yet even most of the die-hard Communists struggle to deal with the legacy of the Gulag. On the other hand, they sometimes come across as more sympathetic than some of those who adapted to Russian style "capitalism." Ms. Alexievich does not generally comment on the interviews beyond explaining the details of how she arranged the conversation. She rarely lets the reader know what she thinks; leaving you to draw your own conclusions. My chief take-away? People have an inborn need to believe in something greater than their own self interest. Nationalism, racial intolerance, the arts, philosophy all offer grounds for faith outside of religious belief. And, judging by its ideology, Communism is a heretical offshoot of Christianity and Judaism, offering the goal of "heaven" in the here and now. And Alexsandr Solzhenitsyn was most definitely correct when he said the line between good and evil runs through the heart of every man. The thing is, that the line isn't generally exposed until one is under great pressure. Here in America, we have been fortunate to have had very little of such pressure; Russia, on the other hand, has been a great laboratory of suffering for much of its history. And while we in America celebrated the end of the Cold War and generally forgot all about the former Soviet Union, in Russia the transition unleashed new rounds of suffering. Finally, I had the great opportunity to visit the Soviet Union in 1990, in the last days of the Soviets. This book makes me wonder how things turned out for my friends from that visit.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: When I was young, Reese's Peanut Butter Cups used to have a series of adds in which one person would be walking with a chocolate candy bar and would inadvertently run into a person holding an open jar of peanut butter. This book reminds me of that commercial; I imagine Mr. Makine putting down the Gulag Archipelago and then picking up Robinson Crusoe and going aha! I won't give away the plot, but this is a fast moving, highly entertaining story. But, upon further reflection, the details don't jibe and the magic spell disappears.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Contains "Protogoras", a refutation of the "sophist" view of philosophy, "Symposium," an examination of the nature of love, "Phaedo," examining the afterlife and "The Republic". Since I had recently read The Republic, I skipped it this time around.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Bruce Springsteen hit the big time when I was in high school with his album "Born in the USA." This is when I first became interested in his music. In college, I explored his earlier albums such as "Born to Run" and "The River" and while he continued to make albums, I found his earlier work more interesting than his later work. As he released "Tunnel of Love", "Human Touch", "Lucky Town" and the rising, I continued to buy the albums and enjoy the music, but his songs just did not contain the same power or interest. I felt that in his early music, he was telling the stories of real people in real life; in his later work he was more often standing on a soap box and preaching. As an illustration, consider the opening lines to "Thunder Road" from "Born to Run", released in 1975. "The screen door slams, Mary's dress sways / Like a vision, she dances across the porch as the radio plays / Roy Orbison singing for the lonely / Hey, that's me, and I want you only …" In this song, the listener is transported to a particular location in a particular moment in the lives of two characters - the unnamed narrator and his girl Mary. Now take the song "You're Missing" from "The Rising" released in 2001: "Shirts in the closet, shoes in the hall/ Mama’s in the kitchen, baby and all / Everything is everything / Everything is everything / But you're missing …" The earlier song, dealing with the angst of two young lovers, is much more compelling than the later song dealing with the angst of those who lost loved ones in the 9/11 attacks. Now this is a long-winded introduction to my feelings about the work of Bruce Springsteen. I love his early work, like his later work, admire the energy he brings to his live performance (although I have never personally attended a concert) and find little interest in what he says or does outside the world of music. And this observation is my segue into my review of his autobiography written in 2016. First of all, props to Mr. Springsteen for not using a ghost writer. And while a ghost writer might of tightened up some sections of the book, I don't thing anyone could have written this story as well as Mr. Springsteen. For he writes his story with all the brilliant details that I love in his early work. For instance, he describes his childhood memory of his mother getting ready to go to work by describing the sounds he heard as she did her hair and put on her makeup. As well as his eye (and ear) for detail, he is very honest and forthright about the emotional turmoil in his home life as a child, his attempts to reconcile this conflict as an adult and his struggles with his father's (and his own) bouts of mental illness. He is a brash, energetic and bombastic showman with a wide streak of self-righteousness and that is conveyed in his writing (and generally recognized and acknowledged.) So the reader has to take this book with at least one grain of salt. He has a natural tendency to rebel against authority yet has no problem exerting his own authority in shaping and implementing his artistic vision (again, something he recognizes and acknowledges.) But he is also quick to acknowledge that he is anxious, self-conscious, insecure and unsure of what to make of his success. And he a strong belief in the love of family and friends and band mates and his place of birth; as well as an unorthodox but strong faith in God. I was expecting an entertaining book chronically the "high life" of a rock star - and was not disappointed in this regard - but what I really found was an extended meditation on love, family and faith. In Anna's freshman year humanities seminar at Notre Dame, she had to read Aristotle's "Nicomachean Ethics" and write an essay examining whether LeBron James exhibited the qualities of one who lead the "good life." Bruce Springsteen would have been a much more interesting case study. Aristotle defines the virtues necessary for the "good life" as a balance between two extremes - courage is the mean between lack of courage (cowardice) and too much courage (rashness). Someone, like Bruce, with a lack of musical education and a poor singing voice may never have ventured onto a stage, and thus have succumbed to cowardice. On the other extreme many rock stars have rashly pushed their life style to a foolhardy extreme and have died an early death. Although Bruce never acknowledges Aristotle, he does discuss the virtues that were necessary for his success and acknowledges his fear of loosing control of himself. Aristotle distinguishes between practical wisdom and contemplative wisdom. Practical wisdom in Bruce's case being his mastery of the details of guitar playing, song writing, performance and the production of music. Anna noted that for Lebron, you could see evidence of the virtues and of practical wisdom but there was no public evidence of contemplative wisdom. Bruce, in his autobiography does provide indication that he thinks about his actions in a bigger scheme than just his own life. I would say the act of writing his autobiography was itself an act of contemplation. While in some areas he can be said to lack wisdom in spite of his contemplation, I think that in what he has discovered that is of most importance to him, he has achieved some level of the good life. But his biography is not an essay on Ethics; I suspect that if anything Bruce would say it is a mediation on life and art. As he state in the book "Life trumps art - always" and this is the chronicle of a real life that is every bit as compelling as the best of his early work.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Audio Book. Mr Gaiman put his own spin on a collection of Norse myths. At times, he is a bit too colloquial but only rarely. I was generally struck with his distinctive style. His prose can be as serious and poetic as a modernized version of the King James Bible, and also funny without being silly. And he reads his own book for this recording. At some points, his voice can be too swarmy and cute, but again this is the exception more than the rule. His British accent does a good job of making the myths seem "foreign" and he has a way of enunciating each and every syllable of a word that engages the listener's attention.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Steve Martin's partial autobiography; covering his life up to the end of his career in stand-up comedy in the early 1980's. I was hoping for a witty and entertaining account story, but this is instead the standard rags-to-riches account of hard-work and persistence. Nothing wrong with that, but little of his humor comes through. Mr. Martin reads his own book and what is most surprising is that the reading is rather flat.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: "Life in China's Surveillance State." Poorly written account of Xi Jinping's attempt to fully assert the power of the Communist Party in China. Mr. Strittmatter has lived in China for quite some time, and he offers a "peek behind the curtain" of censorship and propaganda. But he alternates between excessive fear over the use of technology to enforce dictatorship and a more reasoned recognition of the great weakness in a heavily bureaucratic party attempting to achieve its desired goals. Basically, a waste of time.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Audio Book. I have never been much into mysteries. But this one was very entertaining and I don't mean that in a negative sense. The plot and setting are highly contrived to allow the crime investigation to move in a brisk and orderly fashion, but Ms. Christie also engages your attention with her style and dry wit. The actor reading helped somewhat - he sounds British and he nailed the English, Belgian and French characters while struggling with the American and Eastern European characters.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A novel written in the early 1600's and a translation from the mid 1700s; although some of the vocabulary is archaic, it is easily understood. A biting satire on chivalric romances that offers insight into a culture that still remembered and valued the ideals of chivalry even as society had long moved past the Medieval Period.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Audio Book. Edison is a tremendously interesting personality, and Mr. Morris does a respectable job covering his personal life with his work as an inventor and entrepreneur. But this book has a fatal flaw. Mr. Morris covers Edison's life backwards - beginning with his last years, then moving backwards one decade at a time. I seem to remember some hullabaloo about this approach with another Morris biography (Reagan, perhaps?). But this is the first work by this author that I have read, so I can't say for sure. What I can say is that I am not a fan. It would make sense if he wanted to examine particular effects of Edison's career and then work backwards to the causes. But he simply starts at the end, jumps back 10 years to cover the decade in chronological order, then repeats until he reaches Edison's birth. Personally, I was annoyed by the approach. I am left with the suspicion that he does not want the reader to reach his own conclusions as he works through the material. The second big complaint is that he does not cover in great deal the impact that Edison's inventions had on society. Of course, it is impossible to overlook the impact of his perfection of the incandescent light bulb and the means to distribute power efficiently. But he doesn't go beyond the obvious. On the plus side, his style is engaging and his approach is balanced when evaluating issues relating to competing claims on patents.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Recommended by my friend Ed Schmitt. A fictional embellishment of a true (and very interesting) story, but not well written. To simplistic, as if Mr. Sullivan were writing a movie script instead of a novel. Mr. Sullivan has some difficulty putting the characters in their historical milieu and they come across as modern people dropped into an earlier time. For instance, at one point a stranger offers the family a drink from his whiskey bottle. One young lady is eager to accept, but is prohibited by her mother. The girl complains "But Mom, I'm 21 years old" as if the American drinking age laws applied in World War II Romania. But Mr. Sullivan does introduce the reader to an unforgettable character - Corporal Gheorghe. His musings on life, faith and destiny are compelling and provide an unexpected depth to an otherwise simplistic novel.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: I am a big fan of Dr. Guelzo's history of the Battle of Gettysburg, and enjoy his essays in the Wall Street Journal and First Things. So I was anxious to read his treatment of General Lee. As a biography, his book was somewhat disappointing in that it offered a straightforward retelling of his life with an emphasis on trying to understand Lee's personality and motivations. Dr. Guelzo is neither blinded by admiration nor scorn in treating his subject. But what makes this book interesting are its introduction and conclusion. In the introduction, Dr. Guelzo asks the question of why one should expend effort on writing the biography of one who was a traitor to his country. And that is one of the themes of his coverage of Lee's life - examining how someone whose political sympathies (inherited from his prominent family) seemed to lean of the nationalist Federalist / Whig viewpoints rather than the sectarian Democrats could turn his back on his country at the moment of supreme crisis. He seems to think that Lee's decision was driven by his loyalty to his family and since his family owned land in Virginia (most notably right across the Potomac from DC at Arlington) and his family stood to suffer if that land were threatened, he cast his lot with his native state. Then, in the conclusion of the book, Dr. Guelzo examines Lee's legacy - first in the South and then in the present day with its fixation on identity politics and a widespread desire to erase any memory of the Confederacy. Guelzo is puzzled that our contemporaries look on Lee with disgust since he fought to preserve slavery (and, by extension, the concept of "white supremacy.") Lee certainly believed that free black slaves were not worthy of full citizenship or of social equality. But his views on this were little different than the vast majority of white Americans in 1865. Guelzo points out the Lee professed willingness to drop slavery to preserve the union, actually freed his own slaves during the course of the war, and by wars end was advocating the enlistment of slaves with the promise of freedom. Guelzo does not make this point to justify Lee - noting that he was fighting to defend a rebellion motivated by the preservation of slavery. But Guelzo is puzzled that modern society condemns more his attitudes on race rather than his decision to betray his country. And this is a view with which I have some sympathy. My time on active duty in the Navy was spent stationed in the south and found it ironic that military bases were named for people who fought to destroy their county. One aspect of Lee's decision that I thing Guelzo overlooks is the difference in one's political loyalties for people in 1860 than in 2021. I know no one, (with the possible exception of a stereotypical Texan) who would place their loyalty with their state rather than with their nation. But I think that for many in the early years of the United States, the decision would not be as clear.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Before the Revolution: America's Ancient Pasts

d:simplesect.d:para: Borrowed from Thomas. Covers the history of North America prior to the conclusion of the 7 Years / French & Indian War. Mr. Richter emphasizes the cross-Atlantic interaction of cultures - this provides a much broader view of cultural and economic influences than is usually provided. He does not have an axe to grind, and presents the positive and negative aspects of all involved. He makes one observation that I found unconvincing, noting that the period of Gothic cathedral building in northern Europe roughly corresponded to the period of mound building and Pueblo construction in North America. He speculates that global climate change was somehow responsible; yet cathedral building had been going on in Europe long before the Gothic period. That observation aside, he is surely correct that the even in the late mediaeval period changes in climate had wide ranging economic and political ramifications.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: From Thomas' collection of books. This is a collection of four "epics" from 12th century Constantinople - it is a misnomer to call these works "novels." And all four works tell essentially the same story - a young man and woman fall in love, elope by ship to marry without parental permission, are captured and sold into slavery, and miraculously are re-united with each other and with their parents.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: John Quincy Adams: A Public Life, A Private Life

d:simplesect.d:para: Audio book. A reasonably competent biography marred by an annoying reader. The best part about this book is the use the author makes of JQA's diaries and letters. What I found most interesting was his treatment of Abigail Adams. Based upon Page Smith's biography of John Adams, we are left with the impression of an intelligent and charming woman who participated in a loving and supportive relationship with her husband. And it is my impression that she is regarded as one of the most popular and accomplished first ladies (and by popular, I mean with the opinion of present day Americans.) But Mr. Nagel, while noting the positive aspects of her character, also presents an less appealing side - that of an over-bearing, critical and demanding mother (note, John is also portrayed as an over-bearing, critical and demanding father.) For all his education, experience and accomplishments, JQA comes off as insecure, anxious and neurotic. Indeed, by Mr. Nagel's view, these traits describe nearly all the members of the Adams family (with the possible exception of JQA's sister Abigail). I found this portrayal to be particularly thought provoking when contrasted with Alasdair MacIntyre's examination of "virtue." The John, Abigail and JQA all believe fervently in a sense of virtue very compatible with Aristotle's "Nicomachean Ethics" and "Politics." Yet, by their own words and examples, they come across more as "Pharisees" who are as much motivated by public perception as they are of a true love of what is good. Indeed, the exhortations to virtuous behavior are often accompanied by threats of the loss or withholding of love and esteem. It seems odd that something that should offer so much benefit can be attended by so much angst. By coincidence, during Advent, I read the "Vine and Branches" discourse in John Chapter 15, in particular verse 10: "If you keep my commandments, you will abide in my love, just as I have kept my Father's commandments and abide in his love." Equating the keeping of the Old Testament commandments with the concept of promoting the classical virtues, it would seem that Christ calls us to be virtuous in order to grow in love rather than simply to avoid damnation. But these are just my ruminations; this biography does not deal with such philosophical speculation.

d:simplesect.label: bookOfTheYear
d:simplesect.d:title: Book of the Year
d:simplesect.d:para: The most entertaining was Wodehouse's Right Ho, Jeevess. The best military history was Bolger's The Panzer Killers. The hardest to read, but most thought provoking (and the one I am most likely to read again) was MacIntyre's After Virtue .

d:simplesect.label: review
review

d:title.d:emphasis: Against the Tide: Rickover's Leadership Principles and the Rise of the Nuclear Navy

d:simplesect.d:para: I entered the Navy on July 7, 1986 when I was inducted into the Naval Academy. On July 8, 1986 Admiral Rickover died. I had never heard of Admiral Rickover, and even if the news of his death had been relayed to us newly minted plebes, it left no impression on my memory. However, by the time I graduated from Annapolis I was fully aware that the Navy still walked in his shadow. In my time at Annapolis, I can recall three people with larger than life reputations among the midshipmen. First was Col. John Ripley whose exploits at the Dong Ha bridge in Vietnam were commemorated in a small diorama in Memorial Hall. Next was James Webb whose novel "A Sense of Honor" was the source of controversy at Annapolis and whose short stint as Secretary of the Navy was the source of controversy on the national political scene. Admiral Rickover was the third - in addition to being the father of the nuclear navy and the namesake of the engineering building at Annapolis; the stories of his practice of personally interviewing all officers who were candidates for the submarine service were still recalled with both humor and horror. The one story I recall is that one ensign was asked by Adm Rickover to do or say something that would make him upset. After a moment's consideration, the ensign picked up the model submarine from the Admiral's desk and smashed it to pieces.

Rear Admiral Oliver states that his goal was to write a study on Rickover's management style with an eye towards application in civilian business. Personally, I think that his book is closer to a memoir based upon his personal interactions with Rickover. While some of the myths that surround Rickover are confirmed, his actions are explained as a largely successful effort to deploy a new (and potentially dangerous) technology while simultaneously transforming Navy culture to properly handle this technology. Given the successful outcome of his efforts, he certainly must be ranked as the most influential Navy admiral in the entire Cold War era. RADM Oliver makes a distinction between leadership and management and asserts that Rickover was not a leader but a phenomenally successful manager. But I believe that RADM Oliver is too narrow in his definition of a leader. He equates leadership with the concept of "command presence" and links this vision of leadership closely with the ability to successfully exercise command at sea. He implies that the "command presence" model of leadership is very similar to business leadership. And because Adm Rickover's personal skills were deemed lacking long before the current era of extreme "political correctness," he fails as a leader in RADM Oliver's eyes. But he undercuts his own argument when he examines Rickover's seeming ability to predict the future and his success in creating an effective and safe nuclear Navy. I would argue that Rickover illustrates the classic tension between leadership in unforgiving wartime conditions versus that in everyday life. Be that as it may, RADM Oliver has succeeded in illuminating the "man behind the myth" in a thoughtful and highly entertaining way. Indeed, given RADM Oliver's masterful "sea stories," this book is an early candidate for the most entertaining book of 2022.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A mystery recommended by Nick Salafski; Stacy and I gave it to Anna for Christmas. Mr. Horowitz is a capable story teller; and since I am not a huge fan of mysteries, he was able to hold my attention, although my interest did start to wane at points in the middle of the story. The premise of the book was quite clever, but in the end I can't say I loved the book. Oh, and Anna didn't hate it, but didn't love it either.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Stacy and I gave this book to both Thomas and Anna for Christmas. A collection of short stories by an Orthodox priest. Each of the stories involve an Albanian Orthodox priest - Father Zaum - and episodes in the fictional parish of St. Alexander the Whirling Dervish in northeastern Philadelphia. I suspect that these stories are Fr. Siniari’s equivalents to RADM Oliver's sea stories; instead of reflecting on the leadership qualities of a great navy admiral, these stories reflect on what it means to be a good priest. In terms of style, Fr. Siniari really could have used a good editor, there are moments when he seems to want to avoid being wordy but leaves the reader somewhat confused - usually this happens when the action in a story jumps from one time period to another. In spite of these difficulties, the stories are actually quite moving.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Audio book. The basic plot is interesting, but coming to the story after nearly a lifetime of exposure to a seemingly endless series of adaptations, it has lost its ability to surprise. Stylistically, I would classify this as late Romantic in tone and it is easy to contrast the novel with Frankenstein - an early romantic piece. Frankenstein succeed better as a philosophical reflection on science and morality; Dracula is more a reflection of modern society's unease with a skeptical scientific outlook that claims to explain all. Also, it is an interesting treatment of the cream of society who have been raised in a thoroughly Christian (and Protestant) society, but who think primarily in scientific and economic terms and secondarily in Christian outlook. Dracula's greatest fault is that Stoker's primary tool to create dramatic tension is to place innocent women into mortal peril. I would have overlooked this, but once he killed off one female character, he found it necessary to almost immediately place another women into the same straits. its characters are far too wordy. This is compounded by the quality of the actors reading the story. Mostly they do a good job, but the actor's rendition of VanHelsing nearly drove me to abandon this book. In addition to being an awful attempt at a Dutch accent, each syllable was enunciated and drawn out ( for instance Madam Mina became MadaaMEEEEna) and probably added an extra half hour to the recording.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:simplelist.d:member: Author: Nick Nicholas and George Baloglou, trans.

d:simplesect.d:para: Another book from Thomas' course on Byzantine literature. This is a short poem by an unknown poet regarding a convocation of all the animals called by the king Lion. The purpose of the meeting is allegedly for the animals to speak and learn about each other. Yet after a series of testy, boastful and mocking exchanges, the Lion launches a pre-emptive assault by the carnivores upon the herbivores. Most of the book consists of commentary by the translators, trying to determine how far this work should be read as social or political satire on late Byzantine society. A nice feature is a section of black and white copies of illustrations from a manuscript copy held in Istanbul. Overall, not particularly interesting to the modern reader, but it is useful to see what people in other times and places found to be entertaining.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Palmer and Weaver: Together We Were Eleven Foot Nine

d:simplelist.d:member: Author: Jim Palmer and Jim Dale

d:simplesect.d:para: Ordered this book mostly for nostalgic reasons. When I was a kid, the Orioles, managed by Earl Weaver, were one of baseball's best teams and Jim Palmer was the most recognizable player. Weaver was famous (or infamous) for his tantrums directed at umpires when he disagreed with their calls and the relationship between Palmer and Weaver was known to be combustible as well. This book is a collection of anecdotes by Palmer, mostly relating to his interactions with Weaver. Conversational in style, (I'm guessing Palmer told stories and Dale wrote them down) and told mostly for entertainment. Palmer occasionally has an axe to grind, but mostly all is in good fun. As an aside, in the late 1970's the Johns Hopkins Medical School would host a cookout in the bullpen of Memorial Stadium and Nanny took us a couple of times. In the course of the festivities, a few players would swing by for autographs. Mostly they were backups such as Dave Skaggs or of lesser star power such as Rick Dempsey. But the highlight of my experience was when Jim Palmer wandered over to the fence separating the bullpen from the playing field and signed autographs.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: A Journey Through Texas: Or a Saddle-trip on the Southwestern Frontier

d:simplesect.d:para: The middle of three volumes covering Mr. Olmsted’s travels through the south in the years just before the Civil War. At the time, he was a part-time farmer and a part-time journalist. He had a particular interest in the social and economic impact of slavery in the south. While he encounters no particularly interesting adventures, he offers a vivid portrait of how life was lived in the regions through which he travelled.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Mr. MacIntyre's contribution to the Gifford Lectures given at the University of Edinburgh. ??? Gifford endowed the lectures to carry on discussion of theology in general and moral inquiry in particular. MacIntyre examines the assumptions made by Gifford, and labels this period in the development of moral inquiry as the "encyclopedia" phase. It was based on the assumption that theology would develop along the same lines as the physical sciences and that all subjects could be fully developed and understood in light of the standards developed in the Enlightenment. Mr. MacIntyre then notes that in the present day, the fragmentation of philosophy into multiple "schools" that are mutually unintelligible has proven that Gifford's assumptions have not borne out. He then points to Nietzsche's The Genealogy of Morals as the breaking point of the encyclopedic approach. He labels this group as the Genealogists, who argue that there is no common understanding or even possibility of common understanding given that all morality is a reflection on the individual's will to power. MacIntyre notes that both the encyclopedic and genealogical approaches are united in their rejection of the traditionalist approach as created by St. Thomas Aquinas. But MacIntyre, as a committed "Thomist" suggests that the only possibility of these three approaches to ever exam each other's approaches critically is to follow in the footsteps of Aquinas. He then explores how Aquinas learned from both the Augustinian theology/philosophy dominant in his day and the rising influence of Aristotelian thinking. Rather than picking one side over the other, Aquinas' approach was to fully immerse himself in both lines of thinking and only after coming to an understanding of both approaches, to offer a synthesis of the two. MacIntyre then briefly explores how such a process could play out between the three versions of moral enquiry that he has explored. He goes so far as to question the ability of the modern "liberal" university to ever justify its continued existence without embracing such an approach. This is a very thought provoking book, but as with After Virtue, his style is dense. It is not uncommon for single sentences to take up a paragraph worth of real estate on the page. I can't imagine having listened to the actual lecture, but maybe it would be more easily understood that way. But for all the philosophical nuance (notice how the term "philosophical" has taken on an almost negative connotation in contemporary English), his suggestion that Aquinas had discovered the best approach to theological / philosophical / moral study is easy to grasp and passes the common sense test of plausibility.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audio book checked out from the library. When I was a boy, Kissinger was one of the most recognizable names of anyone in government. I think that most held him in high regard, but he was also a lightening rod for fierce criticism. Mr. Isaacson's biography is a rather balanced examination of Kissinger's career up through the mid-1990's. Isaacson presents all of his accomplishments, but always in a "yes, but" acknowledgement that precedes a discussion of dissenting views and consideration of what Kissinger could have done instead. Stylistically, this makes for a somewhat choppy narrative. Indeed, it is somewhat like St. Thomas Aquinas' Summa Theologica: he presents an episode, then presents dissenting arguments, then supporting arguments, then provides his own opinion. This approach is very thought provoking, but at the end, one is left with the feeling that Kissinger was quite brilliant but would have really been something if he had only shared Mr. Isaacson's view on how to run foreign policy. But personally, after finishing the book, I have a much greater appreciation for Kissinger's intelligence and approach to policy. While Mr. Isaacson may be correct that Kissinger could have been more effective as a manager of a bureaucratic organization and perhaps he would have benefited from being less secretive. But, as Mr. Isaacson says that he worked for Time Magazine he is surely biased to always favor openness to secrecy. And, given the arguments and sources he cites, he is surely of the liberal wing of the foreign policy "Establishment" view that held from the end of WWII at least until the Reagan administration. But, to his credit, he is always at least willing to explore Kissinger's explanation when their views differ. Finally, my favorite anecdote from the book was the description of Kissinger’s boar hunt with Breshnev in Russia. Breshnev had a country retreat and a large stand where he could hunt boar. Before the hunt, the stand was well stocked with food, tea and vodka and the game keeper had laid out a trail of grain to lead the boars within range of the stand.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Audio book from the library. The Library's interface for browsing audio books leaves a lot to be desired; based on the description the book appeared to be about Russia, business and murder. In this case, taking a chance paid off. Mr. Browder has a gift for narrating a story and his account of getting involved in business in Russia in the early 1990's was riveting. But then things became much more serious when I realized that the murder in question was of that of Sergei Magnitsky, who died in detention in a Russian jail. Mr. Browder continues with his efforts to achieve some sort of justice, including the passage of the "Magnitsky Act" sanctioning those involved in his murder. A very entertaining and enlightening book that is clearly intended as one more salvo in his ongoing fight with Russian authorities. If I have one complaint, it is that his attacks on Putin and corrupt officials is painted with such a broad brush that he often appears to paint all of Russia in the same dark tones. For an unsophisticated American audience, this is no flaw, but if he were interested in influence Russian popular opinion this is a big drawback. But that is a minor complaint and does not prevent me from heartily recommending this book.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A very thoughtful and thought provoking book. As the title clearly states, it is about China and does provide some historical background. But it is about American relations with China in particular by the man who helped facilitate the establishment of relations between the US and Red China. The more I read by Kissinger (and about Kissinger) the more I am impressed by his intellectual curiosity and balance; he truly seems to want to understand all sides of an issue rather than shape the issue to fit a particular viewpoint. As an example, I remember the Tianammen Square massacre from my college days, and like most Americans, viewed it through the lens of the last days of the Cold War when there was a feeling that Communism was rapidly collapsing. So the Chinese actions were viewed as the corrupt actions of aging Communists acting against idealistic youths supporting democratic values. Kissinger points out that in the Cultural Revolution, Mao turned the youth of China against all established institutions including the Communist party establishment. Deng was ousted from power and exiled, and his son was paralyzed when he was thrown from the roof of a school building by members of the "Red Guards." For survivors of this period, such as Deng, this was obviously traumatic and also viewed as the waste of 10 years of development in the modernization of China. Not that Kissinger justifies sending in tanks against unarmed protesters, but he offers insight into Chinese leadership that I had never heard from the mainstream media.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audio book checked out from the library. The third time I have read the book. The first time I read it by myself. Next, I read it aloud to Thomas, and this time I listened to it. Tolkien has a gift for creating the most interesting names for characters and places. And this time I was struck by how much effort he put into songs, poems and "languages" for humans, elves and dwarves.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The Great Divorce / The Abolition of Man

d:simplesect.d:para: Two titles in a single audio book from the library. This is the second time around for both of these books. In the Great Divorce, Lewis presents a strong argument to counter David Bentley Hart's argument that in the end all will be saved. Lewis argues that if those in heaven cannot rest content if anyone is not saved, then those who would continue to chose evil would, in effect, hold the heavenly in their control. And in the Great Divorce, he presents plausible examples of those who would chose something else over heaven. But, perhaps, the greatest weakness of Lewis' argument is that his heavenly select seek to convert those at risk of damnation largely through rational argument. I wonder if, at the

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.para: Subtitled "Clues to Our Transcendent Nature from Experience and Reason." Usually I harp upon unhelpful or misleading subtitles to books, but in this case I think the subtitle is more helpful than the title. For while the book presents evidence than mankind had an innate sense of the divine and a consciousness that extends beyond the physical nature of the body, he prefers to refer to "transcendental nature" than to the "soul." I believe this choice in words is driven by Fr. Spitzer's desire to reach an audience of scientists and philosophers. In fact, given the title, I can picture someone looking for some work of sappy earnestness (such as "Chicken Soup for the Soul") picking this book up only to be hit with intricate philosophical points and discussion of quantum physics. It is hard work getting through this book. Stylistically, just as in the first book in this series, Fr. Spitzer's style is pedantic (in a good sense) - he strives for clear exposition of concepts with frequent repetition of key concepts. But perhaps the evidence he provides for trans-physical nature of human consciousness makes the difficult style necessary in order to convince a skeptical scientific audience as opposed to shoring up the conviction of the already converted.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Audio book from the library. Sometimes you get something good when picking a book, and sometimes you get a dud. This is closer to the latter. His subtitle states "What America's Founders Learned from the Greeks and Romans and How that Shaped Our Country." A more accurate subtitle would state "What America's Founders Learned from the Greeks and Romans and How Our Country Rejected that Knowledge." Mr. Ricks sets out with an intriguing idea, examine how an education in the classics shaped four of our founding fathers - Washington, Jefferson, Adams and Madison. But he provides only a cursory examination of the classics and how they shaped each founder; especially when Washington had scant formal education. But Washington could still have provided an interesting case study of Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics in comparing "practical wisdom" against "contemplative wisdom." But Mr. Ricks' knowledge of the classics seems rudimentary and he is content to cherry pick quotes and cite secondary sources. And he diverges far and wide from his stated intention; focusing on a general chronological narrative with excursions into political and military developments. It is telling that his diversions are generally more instructive that his main thesis.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library, this is a collection of articles, essays and letters by C.S. Lewis touching upon Christianity and social issues. While some of his arguments reflect an out-dated worldview of the resident of a mighty colonial power, the conclusions he draws remain relevant. And he deep learning and humility in dealing with issues in which he does not feel himself to be an expert should serve as a model for anyone who seeks to persuade rather than to simply score debating points.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Beautifully written; this book is well deserving of its popularity. Dad says that the depiction of life in Macomb reminded him of St. Mary's county in his youth.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library that I checked out before I had finished To Kill a Mockingbird (TKaM). A few years ago, there was a big deal made about the release of this book. I didn't pay much attention, but it was my impression that this was an unfinished sequel to TKaM and that many people were not pleased with the depiction of Atticus Finch. As I started listening, I was struck by a number of passages that seemed to be taken word-for-word from TKaM - this seemed odd if the book were intended as a sequel. Then I read that Go Set A Watchman was actually an early draft of what eventually became TKaM. I nearly stopped listening assuming that this was a ploy by the publisher to cash in on the enduring popularity of TKAM. But I persevered as I do enjoy her writing. The next hurdle to overcome was what I felt to be an unrealistic attempt to drive conflict when Jean Louise discovers her father attending a meeting at which the featured speaker is an avowed white supremacist. At this point, the work turned from a series of recollections of her childhood that dovetailed with TKaM to a series of angry interior monologues and exterior shouting matches with her loved ones. At first, I found this annoying but figured that Ms. Lee was exploring a number of concepts before settling on the final plot of TKaM. But then I discovered that these monologues, arguments and speeches were actually very thoughtful explorations of southern culture and politics, both dealing with the relations between white and black, between cultured and uncultured whites, and between family members of different generations. As a work of literature, Go Set A Watchman is a failed early attempt as a novel. But as a collection of character sketches and essays, I was fascinated by this book. Ms. Lee pulls no punches in analyzing both the strengths and weaknesses of southern culture and of those who criticize it from the outside. I am amused at the thought of today's shallow, superficial, social-media culture trying to wrap their heads around Ms. Lee's nuanced ruminations.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audio book from the library. Not a typical mystery in which a detective attempts to solve a crime; rather an involved plot by a criminal with the typical emphasis on figuring out "who dunnit?" Well written and entertaining, but utterly improbable. For instance, I doubt whether Ms. Christie ever had personal experience with firing a handgun, or else she would not seriously contemplate a fake shooting inside a house in which no one hears the report of the revolver nor notes the absence of the lingering odor of cordite. But overall, I was willing to suspend disbelief in order to enjoy the tale as if it were a movie thriller with a complicated plot. In the end, although this was intellectually stimulating, it was emotionally unsatisfying.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Maryland Folk Legends and Folk Songs

d:simplesect.d:para: An academic monograph recording "folk stories" gathered in Maryland. The author attempts to record the stories with an emphasis on accuracy in retelling at the expense of style and readability. There is a heavy emphasis on stories of the supernatural and horror stories.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. A sort of morality play set in Saigon in the early 1950's. The quiet American of the title is really not much more than a rather empty foil who drives the conflicts experienced by the much more worldly and cynical narrator. Pyle, the American, is unconvincing; Fowler, the cynical British reporter is more realistic. Overall, entertaining but unremarkable. The actor who read the book was perfect for Fowler, but entirely unable to produce a convincing American accent.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Daniel Boone: The Life and Legend of an American Pioneer

d:simplesect.d:para: Uncle Steve sent me this book; his daughter, cousin Ali, gave it to him after a visit to the Cumberland Gap national park. A solid work of scholarship and a model of balanced evaluation of available evidence.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Streams of Gold, Rivers of Blood

d:simplesect.d:para: Subtitled: The Rise and Fall of Byzantium, 955 A.D. to the First Crusade. In terms of style, cannot compare with Norwich's history of Byzantium. But for detailed research, scrupulous evaluation of available sources and willingness to continually question conclusions, this is top-notch. First and foremost, I am struck by how little primary material is available for what was one of the strongest, richest and most educated civilizations of its time. Next, I am struck by how little credit Basil II is given as a Roman emperor. Certainly all Roman emperors after Justinian are not considered Roman at all by Westerners, but in my opinion Basil II ranks with Augustus, Trajan, Constantine and Justinian. Finally, his final chapter on the First Crusade and the role of the Byzantines is simply outstanding.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Dead Wake: The Last Crossing of the Lusitania

d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. A well-written and even-handed account of the torpedoing of the Lusitania during World War I. Mr. Larsen does a nice job of weaving a large amount of primary material into a fast paced narrative. I found the author reading the book to be a bit "swarmy" in his diction.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Somebody, SOMEBODY has to you see. Then she picked out two somebodies. Sally and me.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The Catcher Was a Spy: The Mysterious Life of Moe Berg

d:simplesect.d:para: A well researched biography of a career bench player in Major League Baseball who also served in the OSS during WWII. Moe Berg was quite a character, who parlayed his minor fame as a player and his contacts from the OSS into a role as a "professional guest" for the rest of his life. Mr. Dawidoff does well to avoid playing the psycho-analyst, but he also had the good fortune to be able to interview a psychiatrist who worked for the CIA and who claimed familiarity with Mr. Berg's case file. No definitive diagnosis is offered, which is intellectually honest.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Part murder-mystery story, part character study and part humorous satire on life in a small town on the Mississippi. It is easy to see why this novella hasn't remained popular. First, while he does consider the folly of human bondage and its degrading impact on human character, today's preference is for this topic to be handled with high moral outrage and condemnation rather than with irony. Second, while the idea of someone being acquitted or convicted based upon finger prints may have seemed groundbreaking at the time this was written, it is now too commonplace to hold the reader's interest.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:simplelist.d:member: Author: Brett Baier with Catherine Whitney

d:simplesect.d:para: Subtitled: Ulysses S. Grant, The Fragile Union, and the Crisis of 1876. Mr. Baier is a TV correspondent and states that he does not view himself as a historian but as a "reporter" of history. At least he is honest, for this book is a rather shallow overview of the life of Grant with a particular focus on the contested election of 1876. For an in-depth evaluation of his life, Bruce Catton and Ron Chernow are much more in depth. I presume that Ms. Whitney has done most of the research; but whoever did the research can be commended for at least providing some fresh sources. For instance, I hadn't realized that Julia Grant had written her own memoir and this book benefits from greater details about Grant's family life. Plus it credits Grant with one of the funniest "lawyer" jokes I've heard. During a particularly low point in his life, when Grant moved to Galena, Illinois to work for his father, he walked into a bar frequented by lawyers. "One of the lawyers noticed Grant: 'Stranger here?' he asked. Grant said yes. 'Traveled far?' 'Far enough.' 'Looks as though you might have traveled though hell,' the lawyer joked. 'I have.' 'Well, how did you find things down there?' 'Oh, much the same as in Galena,' Grant deadpanned. 'Lawyers nearest the fire.' "

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: On The Confederate Border: Charles County Maryland

d:simplesect.d:para: This was a Christmas present from Mom. Lesley and Steve know Mr. Bowling as he served as principal at Chopticon for some time. This is a collection of stories, anecdotes and profiles of locations prominent in Charles County during the Civil War.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: This book can be described as a cross between Bram Stoker's Dracula, Harry Potter and the Father Brown mysteries. Set in Europe just after the turn of the 20th century and featuring a multi-national cast of characters, the influence of Dracula is obvious. But Ms. Nicholson's style is much less melodramatic and verbose than Mr. Stoker's. While Athene Howard, the main character, is British her outlook and behavior seem closer to modern day America than to Edwardian England. This, and the supernatural subject matter, recall Harry Potter. The intelligence and wit of some of the members of the religious orders as well as the sneaky way in which Catholic doctrine is espoused bring the Father Brown mysteries to mind. An enjoyable book, but the author seems to be aiming towards a series of books which inevitably detracts from the "literary" qualities of the story.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Catherine the Great: Portrait of a Woman

d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. The sub-title doesn't lie; this was more a personal biography than an examination of her politics and exercise of power. As much as I admired Mr. Massie's Dreadnaught and Castles of Steel, this work wasn't up to the same standard. Like most modern Western historians, he seems to have only a superficial understanding of the Orthodox Church. Although his constant misuse of the "Mass" instead of "Liturgy" in reference to Orthodox Church services may seem perhaps a superficial complaint, I think it is a perfect example of his lack of understanding. Nevertheless, Catherine's rise to power was quite remarkable and Mr. Massie lists her as one of the two most important and influential Tsars in Russian history (there is a reason both Peter I and Catherine II earned the sobriquet of "the Great".) But the breadth of analysis of her reign does not show the same insight as that of his coverage of Lord Salisbury or Winston Churchill in his naval histories. Interestingly, some of the incidents in Catherine's reign could have been taken from today's news headlines. For instance, the handling of the Moscow plague in the early 1770s and the conflict with the Turks in what is now the southern Ukraine, involving the Crimea and cities such as Mikolaev and Odessa. The other interesting point he makes is that the story of the "Potemkin villages," supposedly staged by Grigory Potemkin as Catherine traveled through he recently acquired territory along the Dnieper River, is most likely false. Indeed, Massie holds Potemkin in high esteem.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: At the Back of the North Wind

d:simplesect.d:para: This book is one of those that is difficult to assign a number grade. One one hand, the plot and style are typical of the Victorian era. For some reason I was reminded of Black Beauty, although it has been many years since I've read that book. But the unique images he conjures outside the realm of the "real" world are fascinating. His "nursery rhymes," often variations on very famous rhymes such as "Little Bo Beep" are very well done. I particularly enjoyed the fairy tale "Princess Daylight." There was a period in my reading life, around the time I was in fifth and sixth grade, where I particularly enjoyed collections of folk tales. While this book is too long to be considered a "tale," it's atmospheric effect is similar. Plus, Mr. MacDonald has a wry sense of humor. The main character is Diamond, and at one point in the story some is reported as having complained that this was not a proper Biblical name. Diamond's mother (if I remember correctly) points out - chapter and verse - exactly where in the Old Testament the word diamond can be found.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. I suppose the main topic of the book is Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). The author states that this book grew out of a magazine article that he had written, but it didn’t grow very much. First, the bad. He is who has in interest in a topic, takes a stack of medical and social science studies, and declaims as if he is an expert. He sprinkles his narrative with statistics and citations of studies. But because the book is not particularly well organized, he often contradicts himself. For example, he cites statistics of much lower rates of suicide in the civilian population during wartime, yet provides anecdotes during the Serbian siege of Sarajevo in the 1990's of people deliberately walking into sniper fire to end their lives. He notes characteristics of the lives of indigenous people in the modern era and assumes that the lives of our ancestors was very much the same. He does not seem to cast a critical eye on the studies that he cites. Yet, despite the many flaws in his work, he does ask some very probing questions about why, in the richest society in history, there is so much spiritual malaise (my term, not his.)

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: The literary equivalent of a Hollywood production such as Top Gun. A wildly improbable plot and one-dimensional characters combined with realistic attention to details of the craft (aviation or nautical).

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The Grand Strategy of the Byzantine Empire

d:simplesect.d:para: Luttwak offers a very interesting analysis of why the Byzantine Empire lasted so long. You could learn the main points of his argument by simply reading the concluding chapter. All the preceding chapters due support his conclusions, but not in a well organized, linear fashion. Stylistically, he is a bit flippant at times; not that the book would have been better by being more serious. It seems that when he has an insight onto the Byzantine approach to warfare or diplomacy, he is apt to throw in a comment that ranges far afield but confuses as much as illuminates. I didn't bother recording any examples, as this is a minor complaint. Much more interesting are his investigations into the evolution of the Roman army under the Byzantines; for instance the vaunted Roman legions were replaced by heavy cavalry using composite bows in imitation of the Huns. He also pays much closer attention to Byzantine relations with their neighbors and their efforts in "grooming" their neighbors' neighbors. The following quotes, I think, offer a good summary of his thoughts: "The tacit understanding was that once that the enemy was destroyed, there would be peace. The Byzantines knew better. They knew that peace was a temporary interruption of war, that as soon as one enemy is defeated, another would take up his place in attacking the empire. hence the loss of scarce and valuable soldiers to inflict attrition was irreversible, while the strategic gains could only be temporary. Even the destruction of the enemy was not a definitive gain, because in the unending war, yesterday's enemy could become the best ally. … Whenever possible, the Byzantines tried to avoid the frontal attacks and rigid stands that inflict and cost high casualties, relying on maneuver instead to fight the enemy by raiding on the offensive and by ambushing on the defensive, by containment, by outflanking, and by enveloping, different ways of winning by disruption rather than destruction." pg. 58 "So why would anyone fight in any other way? The first reason is that to uncover the enemy strengths to be avoided and weaknesses that can be exploited, the enemy itself must be understood, and that requires an intellectual effort, and also an emotional effort to overcome hatred, for there can be no deep understanding without empathy. The Byzantines too may have hated their enemies but apparently not enough to prevent them from understanding their characteristics. Even if not blinded by hatred, the powerful and the ignorant may simply lack the elemental curiosity to study the enemy."pg. 287-288

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. I nearly rated this book a 1; and might of done so had not the actor done such a fine job. Mr. Taylor has a gift for writing interesting dialog. His characters are interesting, but not really believable as real people. The plot is ridiculous. But listening to the Irish and Ulster accents as portrayed by the actor was entertaining. Mr. Taylor should forgo novels and write screenplays for television or movie comedies.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Found this at the library. What a disappointment. This book is disorganized, clumsily written and littered with small factual errors. Given the high quality of his earlier works, I have the impression that someone found an incomplete manuscript, stitched the pieces together as well as they could and then sent the work to be printed without consulting fact-checkers or editors. There are numerous small errors, such as the statement that Lee withdrew across the Potomac the evening after fighting ended at Antietam (a day too soon) and that after shooting Lincoln, Booth rode across a bridge over the Potomac to escape into Virginia (he actually rode over the Anacostia River into southern Maryland. And what are we to make of the following passage regarding a military organization entirely composed of black soldiers: "The Ninth Corps, whose regiments had been raised and trained in Maryland, was sent to join the Army of the Potomac in early March, 1864. It was the first black unit to march through Washington. On its way, one of its white officer recorded that, as it passed through Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 'we was stoned by the low people.' " Quite an itinerary - to march from Maryland to DC via Pittsburgh! And there are some simply bizarre observations, such as his comparison of McClellan with George Patton based on the fact that they were both handsome and came from well-to-do families. I'm sure Patton still hasn't stopped spinning in his grave! What saves this book from the lowest possible grade is that interspersed are genuinely interesting observations on the nature of the Civil War. He pays a great deal of attention to the impact of geography on strategy, he examines in some detail how the two sides were able to organize their armies from scratch and he explores what motivate the soldiers to fight under such appalling conditions.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A novella describing an incident in imperial Russia's expansion in the Caucus mountain region. Thomas read this at college and enjoyed it. Certainly it is an interesting examination of live in the Caucus mountain region as the Russian empire expanded into the region.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Every so often, I come back to Faulkner only to be left disappointed. I read As I Lay Dying in college, and The Sound and the Fury in the 1990's. As I Lay Dying was an interesting read, but my main recollection of the novel was a certain disdain for the uneducated, unintelligent characters. All I remember from the Sound and the Fury was the unintelligible first-person perspective of the character suffering from issues of mental development. Faulkner is a capable story teller but I find that something is off in his view of the world. It is as if he is walking through a landscape and pays only slight attention to the whole landscape because he is so focused on turning over rocks to see what creepy-crawlers lie underneath. It is natural to contrast Faulkner with other "southern" writers that I have read: Mark Twain in Huck Finn or Pudd'n Head Wilson, the stories of Flannery O'Connor, or Richard Wright's Native Son. Each of these other writers can be as unsparing in their sometimes scathing portrayals of the Jim Crow south. But Twain possessed an innate faith in the progress of human development, Wright had belief in communism and O'Connor her Catholic faith - each of these outlooks provided degree of hope that the south would evolve. Faulkner, on the other hand, seems only to offer a vision of stoic acceptance of a mean and harsh existence - an existence that can only be endured but not understood. And his characters are somehow too abstract, so that I am left with the impression that I am dealing solely with Faulkner's imagination rather that believable depictions of actual people. So I will set Faulkner aside yet again, perhaps never again to return.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. When Mr. Pomfret sticks to "reporting" the details he has gathered about the development of the close relationship between the US and Polish intelligence services, this book shines. But too often he editorialized, with the depth and subtlety of a freshman international relations student.

d:simplesect.d:para: Part etymology of words in Old English and how they evolved into modern English and part examination of what the surviving Old English words tell us about Anglo-Saxon life and culture.
