d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Subtitled: An Unorthodox Guide to Making Things Worth Making. An audio book from the library; I had read a review of this book in the Wall Street Journal. Mr. Fadell is an entrepreneur / technology executive whose accomplishments include managing the launch of the iPhone for Apple and the Nest programmable thermostat. I can't say his advice is unorthodox; the basic premise is that all you have to do is follow his example. And he goes to great length in providing detailed guidance on product development and running a technical company. So, if you want to become a CEO or corporate vice-president this book will probably be of use. For a software engineer, there is some useful information but not much.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Uncle Steve sent me this book. It covers much of the same material as "Tribe", but with more narrative content and less spouting a list of social science studies. The focus of this book, however, shifts from the value of a "tribal" culture in supporting an individual to an exploration of what the idea of freedom really means in the modern world.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Uncle Steve sent this to me along with the Junger book. Mr. Bishop is a college professor from Canada who specializes in modern writer (such as Virginia Wolfe and James Joyce) and who happened to love riding his motorcycle. The book is somewhat of a mess in terms of organization, but he writes with an engaging and lightly self-deprecating style that held my interest. When he is writing about riding and road trips on his motorcycle the book is quite interesting. When he writes about his academic research and writing, I was not much interested. For instance, he was quite fascinated by book covers of the early editions of Joyce's Ulysses and by trying to identify who purchased the first 100 volumes of this work. Personally, I really don't care. But then again, I am happy to read about obscure details of Byzantine history, so to each his own. But I can see why Uncle Steve enjoyed the book, combining as it does a love of reading and a love of motorcycles.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Dad recently read The Great Gatsby and said that he really enjoyed Fitzgerald's writing. He thought that his writing was almost poetic. I read the Great Gatsby in high school and wasn't much impressed, but in those days I read fiction in much the same manner as history; focusing on the plot and largely ignoring the style. So I picked up Tender is the Night at a used book store and decided to give Fitzgerald another chance. I must agree with Dad that his writing is very elegant and descriptive. He has a fine eye for detail that does a great job of setting a scene. He is also a master of dialogue. But I find his characters to be either shallow or not-believable or both. The two main characters of this book, Dick and Nicole Diver, are portrayed quite believably in their relationship. But their backgrounds are too perfectly fantastical. The enormously rich and beautiful socialite who is stricken, then recovers from, mental illness. And the middle class man who I supremely intelligent, charming and insightful. Much as modern tabloids portray the rich and the famous today, Fitzgerald seems to first create perfect characterizations so that he can slowly deconstruct the perfection. All of the supporting characters are uninteresting, and with hindsight, seem to be cliched images of the roaring-20's Americans in France. But knowing just a very little bit about Fitzgerald's troubled marriage and his wife's bouts with mental illness, I wonder how much of this book is autobiographical. I think a good contrast to this book is Tolstoy's Anna Karenina - that too is filled with upper-class characters of dubious morality, and a courtship and marriage that are somewhat autobiographical. The difference in the two works, in my opinion, is that Tolstoy's characters seem more real, more believable, less contrived.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Stylistically, rather tough sledding. This book is composed of a set of lectures delivered at the University of Notre Dame, and the purpose of the lectures was to examine how history relates to philosophy (moral philosophy in general, Christian theology in particular). So, it would have been better titled "On the Catholic Philosophy of History." Following the lead of Aristotle and St. Thomas Aquinas, he holds that history, like all human activities, is directed towards a final end. Since modern society tends to ignore "final" ends (as defined by Aristotle) he offers thoughts on how Christians can continue to meaningfully study and contribute to historical knowledge without setting aside their belief in God and the future end of history in the coming of the Kingdom of God.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audio book from the library. A very interesting and though-provoking biography of General Edward Lansdale and the role he played in helping the government of the Philippines defeat a communist insurgency in the 1950's and his attempts to repeat this success in South Vietnam. Given the terribly poor performance of the bureaucrats in the State department and the careerist officers in the Department of Defense in understanding how to manage the crisis in Vietnam, Mr. Boot offers General Lansdale's approach as an alternative - the "road not taken" of the title. In his telling, Vietnam would have been best served by not treating what was primarily a political problem as a military problem. Sure, the South Vietnamese needed economic and military assistance, but they did not need for the US to take ownership of their issues. Perhaps South Vietnam would have fallen anyway, but it would have been at a far smaller cost in lost lives and lost credibility. One of the "losses" attributed to Lansdale is his leadership of Operation Mongoose - the Kennedy administration's hair-brained scheme to overthrow Castro. Lansdale was tapped to lead the effort because President Kennedy admired Lansdale but the CIA, State Dept. and the Department of Defense were adamantly opposed to him playing any role in shaping policy in South Vietnam. While Operation Mongoose clearly failed to unseat Castro, it also did not involve the US in a military conflict to achieve a political goal. More importantly, Mr. Boot can also point to later instances (El Salvador and Columbia) where a more advisory approach proved to be successful. Mr. Boot perhaps would have been better advised to have devoted less coverage to Landale's personal life, but I suspect that he was deliberately trying to "humanize" his subject to counter-act some of the wilder conspiracy theorists who use Lansdale's name in vain (looking at you, Oliver Stone.)

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. We started listening to it on our drive down to South Carolina for vacation, but I wound up finishing it by myself. A very clever and entertaining mystery. I'm not sure how much I would have liked it if I simply read it, but the actor reading the story was really good.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audio book from the library. The word Pioneer encompasses a vast sweep of American history in the west, covering a period from Daniel Boone to the sod-busters of the Great Plains. The focus of this book, most broadly, is the settlement of the Ohio River valley. But more particularly it is about the settling of the "upper Midwest," those states north of the Ohio River. The focus is really on the creation of the state of Ohio but in the end, the book really winds up being a history of the town of Marietta. A wealth of detail focused upon a small place - not badly written, but not particularly interesting.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Recommended by Uncle Steve. This is Doig at his best - portraying men in their struggle to survive in a harsh and unforgiving environment. His laconic dialog is really well done, and his focus on the characters over the plot makes this a deeply interesting story.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Millard Fillmore: Biography of a President

d:simplesect.d:para: From Dad's collection of presidential biographies that he accumulated in his project of reading the biography of each American president. While Fillmore is in some ways one of the most obscure Presidents, his political career was pretty interesting. Although nowadays Henry Clay is probably the most recognized figure in the Whig party, Fillmore was one of the of the major figures in that short-lived party. Interestingly, the Whigs never had a President who served a full term - William Henry Harrison and Zachary Taylor were both elected but died in office and Harrison's VP John Tyler was quickly rejected by the Whig party even while serving out his term. Fillmore, who served out the remainder of Taylor's term, was the most accomplished of the lot. Prof. Rayback portrays him a political moderate whose primary goal was to preserve the Union from sectional forces unleashed by the issue of slavery. But moderation in the "means" of politics does not equate to moderation in the "ends" - for while Fillmore professed to be personally opposed to slavery, he seemed quite content to preserve its existence if that was the price of avoiding conflict. As a result, his most notable political accomplishment - the Compromise of 1850 did long survive his own electoral loss in 1852 and did little to prevent the civil war which broke out in 1860. And while he was a prime mover in the creation of the political organization that called itself the Whig party, the party itself was too divided by competing interests to long survive. And while Prof. Rayback tends to give him a pass as a coalition builder, Fillmore's involvement with such populist movements as the Anti-Masonic party and the anti-immigrant "Know Nothing" party do not reflect highly on his judgement.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. A memoir that is - at different times - entertaining, moving, disturbing and educational. Mr. Vance's parents were born in Appalachia and moved to Ohio, along with many others seeking a better life. But many of the non-economic problems they experienced in the hills of Kentucky were carried with the migrants to their new homes. Mr. Vance was lucky, he had just enough ability and just enough family support to escape a life of poverty and substance abuse. This

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Stacy and I had given this to Thomas for Christmas a few years ago. We knew that it is a collection of stories about Orthodox Christians in contemporary Russia. What I learned upon reading it was that it provided both spiritual edification as well as a fascinating history of the Orthodox Church in the last years of the Soviet Union. While the history of the Russian Orthodox Church in the Soviet Union is a tragic one, Metropolitan Tikhon shows us that it was also a history of patient, courageous resistance that was not without its humorous moments.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Thomas was assigned this book to read as an incoming freshman at Tufts; apparently Mr. Grann received a masters degree at the Fletcher School of International Relations at Tufts. This was an audio book from the library. This is a well researched and well written account of a series of murders of Osage Indians in Oklahoma in the early 1920's and how the predecessor of the FBI (directed by J. Edgar Hoover) claimed success in finding the culprits. There isn't much in American history that I find surprising, but the story of the Osage tribe is completely new to me. On one hand, they were driven to a reservation in Oklahoma like many tribes, on the other, they managed to choose (and buy) a location in northern Oklahoma that they assumed would be undesirable to any farmers. They had the foresight to obtain the mineral rights to the land they purchased, and the apparent good luck to find oil on their land. The tribe had the foresight to manage all the development rights to the oil fields, which brought in a substantial income to their tribe members. But the governments misguided (although probably well intentioned) effort to prevent members of the tribe from squandering their wealth produced a system of guardianship by which most of the tribe had their income managed by outsiders. This naturally produced corruption, exploitation, and worst of all, motivation for outright murder. It is sadly illuminating to discover anew just how depraved humans can be in advancing their own selfish interests at the expense of others. The only reason I rate this book a 3 rather than a 4 is the poor performance of the actors who read the book. The book has three sections, and each section has its own actor. The actor in the opening section was mildly annoying and the actor in the second was a joke - he read as if he were playing the part of grizzled detective in a 1940's film noire movie.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. Interestingly, this book was first created as an audiobook rather than a printed book. One of the shortcomings of the book, in my opinion, is that it is over produced - too many annoying sound effects. On the other hand, it does allow Mr. Gladwell to include interview in the voice of the actual people involved. An Mr. Gladwell does a good job with his storytelling. Anyway, this is a well-balanced and thought provoking account of the proponents of "high altitude" precision bombing during WWII. These proponents are the "mafia" of the title. Unfortunately, with WWII technology, high altitude precision bombing was an oxymoron. As Mr. Gladwell notes, it wasn't until the 1990's that technology caught up with the vision. The most interesting discussion is on the morality of how a bombing campaign should be conducted. The bomber mafia were motivate by both the practical application and a moral imperative of selectively hitting high value targets with a minimum of casualties. The British, on the other hand, were proponents of night time area bombing (what we would call today "carpet bombing") aimed more at breaking the morale of their opponents than in degrading their war time economy. Gen Curtis LeMay, who took over the conduct of the strategic bombing of Japan took the middle road. When it was apparent that high level bombing simply wasn't effective, he adjusted to very low level bombing runs at night using incendiary bombs (napalm). His moral calculation was that the greater brutality of effect was more than offset by ending the war more quickly and thus preventing an even greater amount of future suffering. Mr. Gladwell is clear whose vision he prefers, but he is honest enough to present both sides of the argument. One final note, this is not the first book I've read by Mr. Gladwell - his strength is in asking a lot of questions, trying to evaluate complex issues in a new light and presenting his views in a compelling narrative. His biggest weakness, in my opinion, is that he gets too wrapped up in his own story and is prone to hyperbole and exaggeration. So, I had a quick laugh at his expense. At one point in this book, he wanted to really emphasize the importance of an observation and said something along the lines of "... given the risk of understatement ...". Based on my experience with Mr. Gladwell's writing, he positively has a phobia of understatement! None the less, this is a fine work.

d:title.d:emphasis: The Making of Europe: An Introduction to the History of European Unity

d:simplesect.d:para: Mr. Dawson explores how a common European culture developed during the early middle ages, the time popularly known as the "Dark Ages." He traces the influences of Celtic, Roman, German, Byzantine and Islamic politics and culture and argues that the final stage of development was the melding of the Christian ecclesiastical culture and the Carolingian military culture under the nominal rule of a Christian emperor between 1000 and 1100 AD led to what we now know as a European identity.

d:simplesect.d:para: A satirical take on the British upper-class in the early days of WWII. Mr. Waugh is witty and at the same time somewhat melancholy. If you didn't know that this was the first volume of a trilogy, the abrupt ending would have been quite jarring.

d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. Mr. Hornfischer's final work. In fact, he died of a brain tumor shortly before completing the book and his wife wrapped up the lose threads. This covers the history of the US Navy in the early years of the Cold War, ending with the election of Kennedy in 1960. This is not as riveting as his books about the US Navy in WWII, but is still well worth the time. The actor reading the book was quite slow in his diction; setting the playback speed to 125% got him to what I would consider a normal pace.

d:simplesect.d:para: Although set in Russia just before the emancipation of the serfs in the 1860's, the subject matter is timeless. Two sons return from college educated in the latest "nihilist" views and two fathers of a liberal bent struggle to understand how they seem to have fallen behind the times. By way of analogy, think of a contemporary American college student coming home and expounding upon his "woke" left-wing ideology to his parents reared in the liberalism of the 1960's and 1970's. Turgenev is fair to both points of view but is not up to the task of making this a realistic or interesting portrayal - the novel lacks the charm of Tolstoy, the psychological depth of Dostoevsky or the moral vision of Solzhenitsyn. Frankly, this book was boring.

d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. After setting this aside for a few days, have decided to give up on this book for now. Normally, I would give a grade of 1 for this, but there are some redeeming qualities to Mr. O'Toole's writing that may prompt me to return to finish the book at a later date. First off, it is important to note the subtitle: A Personal History of Modern Ireland. This reveals the book's greatest shortcoming - treating Irish history as if it started with the author's own birth. Sure, he reflects on the impact of the 1916 rising, the struggle for independence and the Great Depression, but he holds he own experiences and those of his own family as the epitome of modern Irish culture. In some ways, this isn't a terrible choice. His observations and interests cover a wide range, and he is generally able to present multiple viewpoints on a given issue. On the other hand, we learn that as he grew up, he was the "fair-haired" child. For instance, when he was very young and his family visited his grandmother, his older brother his behind his mother while he ran and sat on his grandmother's lap. He relates that his grandmother warned that his older brother would come to no good. This is almost a throwaway detail, but I think it illustrates the author's self-regard. We learn that his essay was selected by his teacher as the best in his class, that he was chosen to sing the patriotic song at the school assembly, that he was chosen to be the choir boy when the Archbishop visited his parish, etc. So, I think he views himself as what an Irishman should be, and in this light, his title "We don't know ourselves" really means that the rest of you don't know yourselves, but I'm here to enlighten you. This is exacerbated by the fact that he accepts the current, European centered liberalism in which nationalism, religion and tradition are bad things to be discarded in order to achieve a "modern" European identity. His rejection of nationalism means that he can criticise the IRA and the British equally, that he can recognise the role of the Christian Brothers in educating the poor and middle classes of Ireland while unsparingly reporting on their abuses and short comings, etc. So, at times, he is quite thought-provoking on what aspects of culture should be carried forward as the world changes, and what should be cast aside. On the other hand, I would have to categorize him as a cynic when the term is uses in the sense of "a person who believes al people are motivated by selfishness." Ultimately he seems to believe that people are motivated by self-interest (specifically, material self-interest as measured by wealth and power) and they fool themselves when they think otherwise. So, in this regard, he views Pope John Paul II's visit to Ireland as a "reactionary" (his word) attempt to maintain the Church's grip on political power in Ireland, rather than as an evangelical to promote Christian values and warn against some of the darker aspects of modern secular culture. Perhaps because people haven't wholly embraced his own world-view, there is a sense of self-righteousness and anger in his criticisms. At times, he is so critical one wonders why anyone would chose to continue living in Ireland. Finally, I would suggest that for all his perception and learning, he himself doesn't know who he is (in the sense of Socrates' injunction to "know thyself.") He can reject tradition and authority out of hand because they don't hold society together the same way they did in his parents and grandparents generation. But he has accepted new sources of authority to which he seems blind - globalism, liberalism, sexual freedom, etc. And the authorities that he accepts without question have their own orthodoxies which he espouses with the fervor equal to that of the Christian Brothers who provided his education. Stylistically, aside from his acerbic tone, he is too wordy. He seems to think that if one metaphore or simile will shed light on a topic, then a string of three or four in sucession will be even better. In summary, while he is something of a crank, he possesses the ability to make a somewhat dull topic interesting while stimulating thought about Ireland's place in the world.

d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. Perhaps the history of the development of the index is not worthy of a whole book, but Mr. Duncan does an admirable job of making this an interesting history. For any student or reader of non-fiction, the index is a well-known if largely overlooked feature that is simply taken for granted. Mr. Duncan points out that in reality, it is something of an art in determining what to include and how it should be organized. This art, like all art, can be used sarcastically and several funny examples are provided. This, however, reveals one of the drawbacks of an audiobook. An index is a visual tool. When he provides an example of an index, the actor has to read each individual entry. While reading, the eye could quickly take in the same information that requires a minute or two of listening.

d:title.d:emphasis: Where the Deer and the Antelope Play

d:simplesect.d:para: An audiobook from the library. When I was a kid, there was a TV show called "The Gong Show." It was a talent show with three judges who would watch amateur performers and give a grade at the end of the performance. The twist to the show was that if one (or more) of the judges really did not like the performance, they could ring a large gong situated right behind their seats and the performance would be stopped early. Well, four chapters in to this book (read by the author, incidentally) Mr. Offerman gets my first ever Gong. Although I have only seen him in passing, Mr. Offerman is an actor and comedian; in addition I have read at least one interview with Mr. Offerman as an advocate for enjoying the outdoors. So when I read the description of this book and saw that it was inspired, by the writings of Wendell Berry, I thought it might be interesting. But in four chapters (and an introduction) all that I have really come to learn is that Mr. Offerman really has nothing original or interesting to say. Sure, he has an ironic sense of humor, and when he sticks to humor the writing wasn't bad. But he is a big "name dropper," listing his intereactions and friendships with other celebrities and bragging about that time he was invited to dinner with Wendell Berry. This dinner inspires him write a book and to take a wilderness trip with his friends to gather material for said. book. So, like a stereotypical air-headed Hollywood celebrity, he books a high end guided tour of Glacier National Park. As long as he is providing narrative of his trip, the book is somewhat entertaining. But mostly he veers off course on long rants about his political views. The sub-title to this book is "The Pastoral Observations of One Ignorant American Who Loves to Walk Outside." While Mr. Offerman is fond of acknowledging his own ignorance, what he is even more fond of explaining how most other Americans are the true ignoramuses. In four short chapters, he demonstrates a repeated propensity for listening to one expert and then reading a book or two and seeking validation from his circle of friends. Thus armed and deploying a knowing, sarcastic tone, he is eager to instruct one and all on how things really work. So instead of wasting any more time, I have banged the gong and Mr. Offerman's work disappears from the stage (in this case, my phone.)

d:simplesect.d:para: The last of the books from Anna's freshman Humanities Seminar. This book book is somewhat difficult to read. In part, due to the personal nature of St. Catherine's spiritual dialogue with God and in part due to the "stylistic" differences between a woman of the high Middle Ages and one raised and educated in a much different world. Rather than the compelling narrative of a more contemporary spiritual writer such as Thomas Merton, her reflections really demand that the reader slow down and concentrate. But that is the great advantage that a member of a religious order had over one fully engaged in the secular world. And in reading her description of those in her own day who struggle to follow the right path, people today are not much different.

d:simplesect.d:para: When I was a midshipman at the Naval Academy, the Division of English and History gave us a pamphlet of book recommendations that were felt to be beneficial for the professional development of Naval officers. I return to this from time-to-time to see if I have knocked any of the books off the list and to get ideas for further reading. Recently, I noticed this book and was able to find it on Google books. Here is the blur from the pamphlet describing the book: "If any single vessel were to be named as having the greatest impact on maritime history, one of the candidates would certainly be the Confederate raider Alabama. Semmes is also an eloquent spokesman for the Southern view of the Civil War." Another thing I will note, when I was a student, the academic studies of the American Civil War was largely dominated by southerners - the noted publishers were the University of Virginia, the University of North Carolina, and Louisiana State University. Given Semmes' unquestioning acceptance of the view that Africans were inherently inferior and actually benefited from slavery, I cannot imagine that a current edition of this pamphlet would include this book. His views on the issues of race were not solely confined to southerners, many in the north would have agreed with him as would many in Europe as well. And far from being an eloquent spokesman for the "southern view of the war," Semmes is an unsophisticated propagandist. It is my impression that his arguments are solely motivated by self-interest. He argues that Confederates are not traitors to their country because they have been the victims of oppression by the north, although he cannot provide any compelling evidence that this is the case. He simply ignores dissenting southern views (such as those of Andrew Jackson) and writes off northern criticism as either "Puritan" propaganda or economic self interest of Northerners. If a southerner chose to remain loyal to the United States, in his view it was done solely from the chance of receiving a promotion. Yet, by his own admission, he did not resign his own commission in the US Navy until he had been approached by the new Confederate government and offered a position.) Semmes also has a peculiarly self-interested sense of honor. He complains that the USS Kearsarge had wrapped anchor chain around its hull and therefore won a "dishonorable" fight with the Virginia, yet he had no compunction about flying the flag of another country to lull merchant ships into a false sense of security. And, in perhaps the most damning case, he accepted rescue from a British yacht as the Alabama was sinking while 11 members of his crew drowned. Semmes spends far more time trying to pin the responsibility for these deaths upon the commander of the Kearsarge than he does on the actual battle itself. Semmes is an example of the close-minded nature of southern leadership that sparked the civil war and lead to the Confederacy's quick demise. If Semmes (and by extension Jefferson Davis and Robert E. Lee) can only think that virtue lies on their own side and that the north is motivated solely by self- interest, how could they ever anticipate the lengths of endurance that the north was willing to accept in its effort to preserve the union? Semmes can never grasp the point that Lincoln's administration was willing to sacrifice the interests of the northern merchant fleet in order to bring all possible resources to bear on blockading the south. Semmes' impressive tally of ships burned did nothing to defeat the north. And while Semmes can note the effect that the northern blockade had on the south, he can't bring himself to question the wisdom (or lack thereof) of the southern strategy. All he can do is complain that the north had too many resources, the Yankees were too greedy, the British commercial class to self-interested, etc. So, my final judgement is that this book is best left to fade into obscurity. If you want a nuanced reflection on the southern perspective, turn to the memoirs of Sherman or Longstreet. If you want a primer on naval leadership as exhibited in the Civil War, turn to Incidents and Anecdotes of the Civil War by David Dixon Porter or to Mahan's biography of Admiral Farragut.
